SENT.plain: The recent trends in the diagnosis and management of gastrointestinal lymphoma are reviewed
Primary gastrointestinal lymphoma accounts for 30-40% of all extranodal lymphomas, while it comprises only 1-8% of all gastrointestinal malignancies
The most common histological type is mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma, followed by diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
Recently, the incidence of intestinal follicular lymphoma has been increasing
Balloon-assisted endoscopy and capsule endoscopy are essential tools for the assessment of small bowel lymphomas

Treatment modalities for gastrointestinal lymphomas include 'watch and wait' strategy, antibiotics (e.g. Helicobacter pylori eradication), radiotherapy, chemotherapy, surgical resection, immunotherapy (e.g. rituximab), and combinations of these
Optimal therapeutic strategies should be determined based on the involved site, histological type, and clinical stage
It should be noted that accurate pretreatment diagnosis of the disease is most important
